raw_text:
Profile: David Miliband
 
 David Miliband's rapid rise through the ranks of government continues with his promotion to Cabinet Office minister.
 
 Elected in a safe Labour seat in 2001 his previous job was school standards minister - a role he won in May 2002. Prior to the last election he was a key figure in New Labour as the head of the Downing Street policy unit where he was a key member of the manifesto writing team. Seen as one of the more intellectual figures in the government, he was also working for Tony Blair in his policy unit when he was leader of the opposition.
 
 A brief glance at Mr Miliband's family background reveals an impressive socialist pedigree in the form of his father Ralph, who died in 1994. He was an eminent and influential leftwing academic. And while David Miliband is seen as a key Blair lieutenant his brother Ed is a special advisor to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Prior to working for Mr Blair, David Miliband spent time at the left-leaning Institute for Public Policy Research. He then became secretary of the Commission on Social Justice. The 39-year-old was educated at Haverstock Comprehensive before going on to Oxford to study politics, philosophy and economics. He also took an MSc in political science from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
llama3.2:1b: David Miliband's rapid rise includes promotion to Cabinet Office minister, previously serving as school standards minister since 2002. Prior to this, he was head of the Downing Street policy unit under Tony Blair, working on manifesto writing and opposition leadership. Miliband is a key figure in New Labour, joining the team after winning the position for Labour's safe seat in 2001. His family includes an influential academic father and brother who have worked for the government before or after Miliband's careers started.
llama3.2:3b: David Miliband is a senior government minister, promoted to Cabinet Office. He was elected in 2001 and previously held roles including school standards minister and head of the Downing Street policy unit under Tony Blair. His family background includes a socialist father, Ralph Miliband, who died in 1994.
gemma2:2b: David Miliband rose through the ranks of government, becoming Cabinet Office minister after a career in New Labour. His father was a left-wing academic with socialist ties, while his brother works for Chancellor Gordon Brown.  Miliband's background includes working for Tony Blair's policy unit and at the Institute for Public Policy Research before serving as secretary of the Commission on Social Justice.
qwen2.5:0.5b: David Miliband is a prominent British politician who has risen through the ranks of government and served as a Cabinet Office minister. He previously held positions including school standards minister and head of Downing Street policy unit for Tony Blair's Labour Party during his time as leader of the Opposition. He was seen as a key figure in New Labour and had an intellectual presence, working with Tony Blair to draft the manifesto at the time of his election. His political career was marked by his father Ralph Miliband, who died in 1994, making him an elderly left-wing academic figure. Despite this, David Miliband's brother Ed is a special advisor to Gordon Brown and has worked for Labour since he became leader. He graduated from Haverstock Comprehensive before studying politics, philosophy, and economics at Oxford University and later at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, obtaining degrees in political science and another MSc.
qwen2.5:1.5b: David Miliband has risen through the ranks of government after being promoted to Cabinet Office minister following his election as school standards minister in 2002, where he worked with Tony Blair and Ed Miliband before joining the Institute for Public Policy Research and Commission on Social Justice. His socialist background is traced back to his father Ralph, an eminent left-wing academic.
qwen2.5:3b: David Miliband's career has rapidly advanced with his recent promotion to Cabinet Office minister. Elected in 2001, he previously served as School Standards Minister from May 2002. Prior to the last election, he was a significant figure within New Labour, particularly in the Downing Street policy unit where he was part of the manifesto writing team. Known for his intellectual capabilities, Miliband also worked under Tony Blair when he led the opposition and later spent time at the left-leaning Institute for Public Policy Research before becoming Secretary of the Commission on Social Justice. He is son of Ralph Miliband, an influential academic in the socialist movement. His brother Ed is a special advisor to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Educated at Haverstock Comprehensive and Oxford University, he also holds an MSc in political science from MIT.

He was associated with influential political thought there, notably part of the manifesto team. Known for his intellectual appeal, he was criticized by Blair supporters but also faced criticism from those aligned with him. David studied at Haverstock Comprehensive before Oxford to earn a degree in politics, philosophy, and economics and later obtained an MSc in political science from MIT.
tinyllama:1.1b: Key details: David Miliband is a former school standards minister who rose through the ranks of government by holding multiple positions within New Labour and working for Tony Blair's policy unit, before joining the Downing Street policy unit as head of the manifestos writing team. He has family ties to Ralp Miliband, who was an influential leftwing academic and socialist political figure. David Milibaand's brother Ed is a special adviser to Gordon Brown. In addition, he attended Oxford and earned an MS in political science from Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Profile: David Miliband

David Miliband is a rising star in British politics. His early career has seen him climb through various ranks within the Labour Party, eventually making his way to Cabinet Office Minister. Before that, he held a number of key positions including school standards minister and Downing Street policy unit head, where he was a key player on New Labour's manifesto writing team. As a socialist, David Miliband has connections to prominent socialist figures such as his father Ralph who died in 1994.

David Miliband is also seen as having strong political ideals and understanding of the social justice issues that face the country today. He took on Gordon Brown when he was an up-and-coming politician, working for him as a special advisor before becoming Secretary of the Commission on Social Justice.
phi:2.7b: David Miliband, a left-wing academic father of Labour's Cabinet Office minister, has risen quickly through government ranks since 2001, having been previously a school standards minister. A brother of the party leader Ed, he is seen as one of the more intellectual figures in the current administration, with his other background being at the Institute for Public Policy Research and then the Commission on Social Justice. Born in 1975, he studied Politics, Philosophy & Economics and Political Science at Oxford and MIT before going into politics.

Prior to the last election, he was a key figure in New Labour as the head of the Downing Street policy unit where he was a key member of the manifesto writing team. He is seen as one of the more intellectual figures in the government and worked for Tony Blair in his policy unit when he was leader of the opposition. David Miliband's father was an eminent leftwing academic and his brother Ed is a special advisor to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Before working for Mr Blair, David Miliband spent time at the Institute for Public Policy Research and the Commission on Social Justice. He studied politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford and completed an MSc in political science from MIT.
